title: Blog: How to Build My Next.js E‑commerce
excerpt: Welcome to this step‑by‑step tutorial on building a modern e‑commerce website using Next.js, React, and Tailwind CSS. We’ll walk through the entire project called My Next.js E‑commerce, explain its architecture, install it locally, explore key features like the shopping cart and admin panel, and finally deploy it. The goal is to teach you how to structure and understand a real e‑commerce frontend project.

content.text: My Next.js E‑commerce is an e‑commerce app built with Next.js and React. It includes features such as:

items: Product catalog with filters and search
Product detail pages with add‑to‑cart functionality
Global cart management using React Context API
Admin panel for managing products, categories, and users
Responsive design
Next.js – React framework with SSR and SSG
React – UI library
Context API – State management (cart, theme, language, auth)
Tailwind CSS – Utility‑first styling
Netlify – Suggested deployment platform

content.text:
npm run dev
# or
yarn dev
Open http://localhost:3000 to view the application.
Here's the simplified structure of the app:

my-nextjs-ecommerce/
│
├─ src/
│  ├─ app/                   # Main pages & routing
│  ├─ components/            # UI and functional components
│  │  ├─ product/            # Product UI pieces
│  │  ├─ admin/              # Admin Panel
│  │  └─ ui/                 # Reusable UI
│  ├─ context/               # React contexts (Cart, Theme, Language, Auth)
│
├─ public/                   # Static assets
├─ package.json              # Dependencies & scripts
└─ README.md
Users can browse products, view product details, and filter results by categories or search terms.
The cart uses React Context to maintain state globally across the app.
Admins can manage products, users, and categories. This section involves UI components specific to the admin area.
For deployment, you can use Netlify or Vercel. Netlify works especially well for static portions of the site, while Vercel excels with Next.js server capabilities.

items: Push your code to GitHub
Connect to Vercel/Netlify
Add environment variables (if needed)
Deploy

content.text: This blog taught you how to set up and understand a full e‑commerce frontend built with Next.js. You should now feel confident cloning, running, and modifying this project.

title: Tutorial: How to Build Your Own Weather Forecast App with Foreweather
excerpt: Foreweather is a web application that displays personalized weather forecasts using modern frontend technologies.

content.text: Foreweather is a web application that displays personalized weather forecasts using modern frontend technologies. It is built with:

items: React – UI library for reactive interfaces.
Vite – ultra-fast frontend bundler.
Tailwind CSS – utility-first CSS framework.
Open-Meteo API – free weather API with no API key required.

content.text: What Will You Learn in This Tutorial?

items: How to clone and run the project locally
How the integration with the Open-Meteo API works
How the project is structured using React + Vite + Tailwind
How to extend or customize the app (for example, adding geolocation)

content.text: First, open your terminal and clone the repository:
This will download the source code to your machine.
2. Install Dependencies and Run the App
Make sure you have Node.js installed (v14+ recommended). Then install the dependencies:
This will launch a local server (usually at http://localhost:5173) where you can see the app running.
3. How Does the App Get Weather Data?
Foreweather uses the Open-Meteo API, a free weather forecast service that does not require an API key and provides JSON data such as temperature, wind, rain, and forecasts.

title: Snake Game en React — Tutorial
excerpt: A modern remake of the classic Snake game using React.js. It offers smooth movement, a clear user interface, and high modularity.

content.text: A classic Snake game — with board, moving snake, random food, score, high score, pause, and restart — using React, hooks, and CSS (Tailwind or similar).

items: Create a new project with Vite + React or Create React App.
Install React dependencies.
Create folder src/components/ and add components: Board, Controls, GameStats, GameOverModal.

content.text:
src/
│   ├── components/
│   │   ├── Board.jsx/
│   │   ├── Controls.jsx/
│   │   ├── GameStats.jsx/
│   │   └── GameOverModal.jsx/
│   ├── App.jsx
│   ├── App.css
│   ├── index.css
│   └── main.jsx

items: snake: array of segments with {x, y}
food: food coordinates
direction, nextDirection: current and next direction
gameOver, isPaused: game state
score, highScore: player’s score and record
speed: how fast the game loop runs
getInitialSnake(): returns initial snake (3 segments)
getRandomFood(snake): random food position not in snake
resetGame(): reset all states
handleDirectionChange(newDirection): safely change direction (no 180° turns)
togglePause(): toggle pause/unpause
Keyboard listener for arrow keys / WASD / spacebar
Game loop: with setInterval, move snake, check collisions & food, update state
Create a grid of gridSize × gridSize cells.
For each cell, compute coordinates (x, y), check if belongs to snake head/body/tail or food or empty.
Render with different styles depending on content.
Controls: buttons (or keyboard) to change direction, pause, restart.
GameStats: show current score, high score, and status (playing / paused / game over).
GameOverModal: appears when game ends, shows score, high score, and restart button.

title: Creating a Modern React Portfolio
excerpt: Design and code your personal React portfolio with Vite and Tailwind — stylish, fast, and developer-friendly.

content.text: In this tutorial, we will build a personal portfolio using React, Vite, and Tailwind CSS. The portfolio will showcase experience, skills, projects, and include smooth animations and multilingual support.

# Clone repository
git clone https://github.com/faidrn/my-portfolio.git
cd my-portfolio

# Install dependencies
npm install

# Start development server
npm run dev

# Open your browser at
http://localhost:5173

my-portfolio/
├── public/
├── src/
│   ├── components/
│   │   ├── ui/
│   │   ├── sections/
│   │   ├── common/
│   │   └── layout/
│   ├── contexts/
│   │   └── LanguageContext.jsx
│   ├── App.jsx
│   ├── App.css
│   ├── index.css
│   └── main.jsx
├── package.json
├── vite.config.js
├── tailwind.config.js
└── README.md
We use a flexible Tabs component with triggers and content that respond to clicks:

<Tabs defaultValue={0}>
  <TabsList>
    <TabsTrigger>Experience</TabsTrigger>
    <TabsTrigger>Education</TabsTrigger>
    <TabsTrigger>Skills</TabsTrigger>
  </TabsList>

  <TabsContent>Content for Experience</TabsContent>
  <TabsContent>Content for Education</TabsContent>
  <TabsContent>Content for Skills</TabsContent>
</Tabs>
Badges are small labels for dates, skills, or tags:
Inside Resume.jsx, import Tabs, TabsList, TabsTrigger, TabsContent, and Badge. Use state to switch between sections:
Use Framer Motion to animate sections and list items:

<motion.div
  initial={{ opacity: 0, y: 20 }}
  whileInView={{ opacity: 1, y: 0 }}
  transition={{ duration: 0.4 }}
>
  {/* Content */}
</motion.div>
Use LanguageContext to provide translations for labels and text throughout your portfolio.
You now have a modern React portfolio with a responsive design, tabs for sections, badges for details, animations, and multilingual support.
